dialogues.RICKEY:
[1]Gentlemen, I have a plan... As of now, only the Board of Directors and my family know. Sukeforth and Parrott exchange a look. 
[2]My wife says I'm too old, That my health isn't up to it. My son says that every one in baseball will be against me. But I'm going to do it. Parrott looks to Sukeforth who keeps his eyes on Rickey. 
[3]I'm going to bring a Negro ballplayer to the Brooklyn Dodgers. 
[4]There's no law against it, Clyde. 
[5]So be it. New York is full of Negro baseball fans; every dollar is green. I don't know who he is, or where he is, but he's coming. 
[6]No. 
[7]A heck of a player. But too sweet, they'll eat him alive. 
[8]Too old. We need a man with a future not a past. (holds up his own 
[9]A four sport college man, out of UCLA. That means he's played with white boys. Twenty-six years old, now with the Kansas City Monarchs. Batting over 350 even as we speak. 350! And he was a commissioned army officer! 
[10]For refusing to sit in the back of a military bus.  Ft. Hood, Texas. The driver asked him to move back. The MPs had to take him off. 
[11]I see he resents segregation. If he were white, we'd call it spirit! 
[12]Robinson's a Methodist. I'm a Methodist. God's a Methodist. We can't go wrong. Find him. Bring him here. 
[13]Do you have a girl? 
[14]A man needs a family relying on him. It insures he'll behave responsibly. Do you have a girl? 
[15]You think so? Jack looks to Sukeforth who smiles placidly. Back to Rickey. 
[16]Do you love her? Rachel? Don't you know? 
[17]Marry her. What? Rickey stands, walks to a window. Jack looks at Sukeforth who raises a hand as if to say: Give it a chance. 
[18]Baseball's a hard life; a man needs a good woman by his side. You don't want the only person waiting for you at home to be a catcher. Sukeforth chuckles at that. Rickey fingers open a slat on the blind and peers out. Jack looks hard at him. 
[19]This is about baseball. Rickey opens the shade. Sunlight floods in. Rickey follows it to the chalkboard, to the list of players under Montreal. 
[20]I see you starting in the spring with our affiliate in Montreal. If you make it there, we'll try you down here with the Dodgers. The white Brooklyn Dodgers. Jack looks to Sukeforth who nods: Yes, you heard right. 
[21]I'll pay you $600 a month and a $3,500 bonus when you sign the contract. Is that agreeable? Believe it or not that's a lot of money to Jack on this day in time. This is all becoming a bit overwhelming. 
[22]There is one condition. I have a pile of scouting reports. I know you can hit behind the runner, that you can read a pitch. The question is can you control your temper? 
[23]Yes your temper! Are you deaf?! Rickey furious, the avuncular old man gone. Jack sits there, fists now balled. Rickey to Sukeforth like he's not there: 
[24]He looks proud. Willful. 
[25]I want to win! I want ballplayers who can win! Are you one of them?! 
[26]A black man in white baseball. Imagine the reaction. The vitriol. Rickey strides forward, gets in his face. 
[27]The Dodgers check into a hotel. A decent good hotel. You're worn out from the road and some clerk won't give you the pen to sign in. We got no room, boy, not even down in the coal bin where you belong. 
[28]The team stops at a restaurant. The waiter won't take your order.  Didn't you see the sign on the door? No animals allowed. What are you going to do then? Fight him? Ruin all my plans? Answer me, you black sonofabitch! 
[29]I want one who has the guts not to fight back! There are people who will not like this. They will do anything to get you to react. If you echo a curse with a curse, they will only hear yours. Follow a blow with a blow and they will say a Negro lost his temper; that the Negro does not belong. Your enemy will be out in force, but you can not meet him on his own low ground. We win with hitting, running and fielding, nothing else. We win if the world is convinced of two things: that you are a fine gentlemen and a great ballplayer. Like our Savior, you must have the guts to turn the other cheek. Jack considers Rickey. Rickey looks worn out. 
[30]Can you do it? Jack poised at what will be his Rubicon. He crosses. 
[31]Who's the best shortstop you ever saw? 
[32]Rabbit Tavener? And you call yourself a sports writer? 
[33]Pop Lloyd. 
[34]Wagner is number two. And Rabbit Tavener would not break my top 25. Where do you suppose Jackie Robinson will end up on that list? 
[35]Alright then, where would he rate at second? 
[36]High praise. He'll have to be the best in the minor leagues first. 
[37]I'm saying it's going to be a very interesting spring training. A lot of players are coming back from the war and with gas rationing over, we can train down in Florida again. 
[38]Those towns may as well be a million miles from Daytona. 
[39]I spoke to the Daytona mayor. He assures me there'll be no trouble. But Rickey doesn't sound so sure. They consider each other. 
[40]Mr. Smith, are you a Communist? 
[41]I have a business proposition. What's your salary at the Courier? 
[42]I will pay you an additional fifty dollars a week plus expenses if you will attend spring training with Jackie Robinson. You will watch over him, help him to avoid the harm that could come if he were to do or say anything out of turn. You will act as his chauffeur, you will secure accommodations for him wherever the team may be, help him find restaurants, etc... 
[43]Unprecedented access for any reportage you feel appropriate. What do you say, Mr. Smith? 
[44]Ebbets Field actually, but yes, I agree. The world is ready. 
[45]How are they looking, Leo? 
[46]A bus? Harold, how in blazes did he end up on a bus?! BOB BRAGAN, in his catching gear, passing by with pitchers RALPH BRANCA and KIRBY HIGBE. Higbe asides to Bragan: 
[47]Listen to this, Harold. Whenever I hear a white man - yours truly - broadcasting what a Moses he is to the Negro race, then I know the latter needs a bodyguard. (Parrott tries to 
[48]The minor league commissioner of baseball said that! I pay part of his salary! You wouldn't stab me in the back like this, would you? 
[49]Why didn't you say so?! 
[50]Clay, I'd like you to meet Jackie Robinson. Jackie, Clay Hopper, manager of the Montreal Royals. Hopper shakes his hand as they exchange greetings. 
[51]I agree. And I'll state another obvious, Clay, I need the players to act like gentlemen around him. 
[52]To treat him as they would any other teammate. 
[53]To be natural, to impose no restrictions on themselves. To all work together in harmony. WHACK! The hit & run is on. The man on first runs on the pitch as a LOW LINE DRIVE shoots for the gap between 1st and 2nd. Robinson turns himself inside out to dive on his belly and catch it before it hits the ground. He spins himself around, pivots on a knee to throw the runner out before he can get back to first. Â  Rickey is astounded. 
[54]That was superhuman. 
[55]Clay, I realize that attitude is part of your heritage; that you practically nursed race prejudice at your mother's breast, so I will let it pass. But I will add this: you can manage Robinson fairly and correctly or you can be unemployed. They both look over as Jack comes off the field toward them. 
[56]I see... Yes, I understand. Wake him up and get him out of there. Put him in the car and start driving for Daytona Beach. Now. And, Wendell, under no circumstance tell him what this is about. I do not want him to get it in his head to stay there and fight. 
[57]I've spoken to the mayor. I've explained how much money we'll spend in Daytona. But still, when this fine young Negro man steps on that field today, he and the Dodgers will technically be breaking the law. A law which says white and black players cannot enjoy the same field at the same time. Does that make sense to you? Does Jim Crow make any sense when placed against the words of the United States Constitution? When placed against the word of God? POP OUT to reveal he sits beside the DODGER BATBOY, so short his feet don't touch the ground. Rickey offers his peanut bag. As the batboy takes one... 
[58]I'll tell you, it does not make sense to me. 
[59]Watching from a seat behind third. 
[60]Thataway, Jackie! Thataway! Higbe looks home for the sign, Jack dancing off third, pounding his right foot toward home. He feints hard home. Higbe steps off the rubber. Jack stays where he is. 
[61]Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn. 
[62]Me, too. Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack. 
[63]Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement. 
[64]I know that. 
[65]Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back.. 
[66]I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it. 
[67]Don't you believe that? 
[68]Agreed. Therefore, run the bases like the Devil himself. 
[69]Worry those pitchers so they come apart. Sometimes they'll catch you, but don't worry about that. Ty Cobb got caught plenty. Just run as you see fit. Put the natural fear of God into them. 
[70]Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us. 
[71]I have a ballplayer on my Montreal team named Jackie Robinson. The start of applause. Rickey motions for it to stop. 
[72]He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a group of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on: 
[73]I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on. 
[74]You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this!  If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably... 
[75]Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all. 
[76]Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson. 
[77]Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands. 
[78]If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly. 
[79]So you have no objections to him? 
[80]Yes. Oh -- and Leo? 
[81]The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well. 
[82]Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream? INSERT: Panama City, Panama. March 18, 1947. 
[83]A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country? 
[84]You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win. 
[85]Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson? 
[86]And your friends here in Brooklyn?  Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad. 
[87]Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan. 
[88]I received your letter, Dixie. Recently, the thought has occurred to me that a change of ball clubs would benefit both the Brooklyn Baseball Club and myself. This is about Robinson? 
[89]I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something. 
[90]Is that what you're you afraid of?  Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you! 
[91]I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs. 
[92]Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players. INSERT: Brooklyn. April 9, 1947. 
[93]If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal.  For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office. 
[94]Durocher. Of course, he's my ace in the hole. Very good, Harold. The phone still rings. Rickey looks to his open door. 
[95]Jane Ann! Are you out there? Grumbling, brambly eyebrows twitching, he makes the mistake of answering his own phone. 
[96]Branch Rickey... You're speaking to him... The Commissioner of what..? Oh, yes put him on.  
[97]Fine. What can I do for you, Happy? 
[98]I'm sorry, Happy, I thought you said lose Durocher for a year. 
[99]Anyone who sets foot in Havana is seen with known gamblers. 
[100]You're joking. 
[101]Now I'm sure you're joking. Happy checks his nails, returns his hand to the MANICURIST. 
[102]You know very well my organization is about to enter a tempest. I need Durocher at the rudder. He's the only man who can handle this much trouble, who loves it in fact. You're chopping off my right hand! 
[103]You can't do that! Happy, you son of a bitch! DIAL TONE. Rickey steadies himself, looks to Parrott. 
[104]Trouble ahead, Harold. Trouble. 
[105]I'm so sorry about the rush. Events are unfolding too fast to keep up with. The burden has finally fallen to me and so be it. 
[106]Yes, yes. As Jack poises the pen -- Rickey suddenly aghast. 
[107]Stop! The pen a millimeter over the page. 
[108]History. And I'm blabbing, blabbing through history... Rushing it along. What am I thinking? 
[109]Jane Ann, come in here.  Harold! Parrott sticks his head out from an office down the hall. 
[110]Get some employees up here! 
[111]Harold, telegram the press. Say this: âThe Brooklyn Dodgers today purchased the contract of Jackie Robinson from the Montreal Royals. He will report immediately.â 
[112]Opening day, Harold. The world is all future and no past. 
[113]It's a game of inches, Jackie! 
[114]Baseball has returned to Brooklyn, Burt. Another season is underway. 
[115]Inevitable I suppose. I asked him if she was worth it and he said yes. How's the retirement? 
[116]It's a helluva thing when a man has good health and enough money and absolutely nothing to do. 
[117]Is that so? 
[118]Roses and sleep are two wonderful things, Burt. But sleep you can get inside your casket and flowers look good on top of it. You don't look like a dead man to me. 
[119]I need you to manage the Dodgers. We're a ship without a captain; there's a typhoon ahead. 
[120]Do you miss the game, Burt? Look me in the eye and tell me you don't. Shotton considers Rickey a beat and then looks away. 
[121]You promised her you wouldn't put on another uniform. You didn't promise her you wouldn't manage. Wear a suit and tie; Connie Mack still does. You remember how to get to the Polo Grounds, Burt? 
[122]You remember what the peanuts smell like roasting, how the crack of the bat sounds, the roar of the crowd? 
[123]My car's parked right out front. Harold will show you where. Now what do you say? 
[124]What's he saying? 
[125]Stands, watches. Praying this doesn't go south. As Jack finally continues on, Rickey closes his eyes in relief. 
[126]You can't, Jackie. You know it. 
[127]These men have to live with 
[128]You don't matter right now, Jack. You're in this thing. You don't have the right to pull out from the backing of people who believe in you, respect you and who need you. 
[129]If you fight, they won't say Chapman forced you to; they'll just say that you're over your head. That you belong where you are. 
[130]That every downtrodden man who wants more from life is over his head. Jack's either going to explode or break into tears. 
[131]No. You do. You're the one living the sermon. In the wilderness. Forty days. All of it. Only you. 
[132]Of course there is! You can stand up and hit! You can get on base and you can score! You can win this game for us! We need you as well! Everyone needs you.  You're medicine, Jack. Rickey reaches out, touches the wall to stay standing. Jack just breathes as familiar sounds reverb down the tunnel. 
[133]Who's playing first? Jack considers him. Everything hangs in the balance. Then: 
[134]When I first told you about Jackie, you were against it. Now all of a sudden you're worrying about him. How do you suppose that happened? 
[135]Sympathy, Harold, is a Greek word. It means to suffer. I sympathize with you means I suffer with you. This Philadelphia manager has done me a service. 
[136]Is there an echo in here? Yes, he's creating sympathy on Jackie's behalf. Philadelphia by the way is Greek for brotherly love. The intercom BUZZES. 
[137]What in Satan's fire does he want? Send him in. Rickey pretends to review papers as Bragan enters, his hat literally in his hand. Rickey lets him stand there a moment. 
[138]What do you want, Bragan? 
[139]What about Robinson? Bragan's been staring at the floor. He looks up now. The low afternoon sun hits his face. 
[140]Why? 
[141]Red Sox just offered Ted Williams, but I'll see what I can do. 
[142]Do you remember the story, Burt, of the 99 sheep? How one was missing? 
[143]I find myself at odds. I want integration and the pennant. I want to punish Dixie and at the same time I want his salvation. 
[144]It would be so much simpler if he wasn't batting .385. As Walker finishes, he passes Jack whose turn it is. 
[145]Nevertheless it must be accepted calmly, Harold. What is it? A headline: PLAYERS STRIKE. Parrott reads... 
[146]Madness! What are they thinking?! 
[147]National League President Frick says this is America and baseball is America's game. He says one citizen has as much right to play as another. Baseball will go on as planned once the rain stops. Jack eyes his bat. 
[148]Because my job is to win. I have an obligation to Brooklyn to put the best team on the field I can. Your presence on the roster increases our chances of winning. Not buying it, Jack looks over at him. 
[149]You look lovely, Mrs. Robinson. 
[150]I don't know how you do it. Every day, from the 1st to the 9th. Myself? I could pay $100 for a suit and in twenty minutes I'd look like I fell out of bed. Even my shoes look rumpled. They watch Jack crack one high off the Schaefer Beer sign. 
[151]Is that so? 
[152]How did you two meet? 
[153]Trying to catch her in a race. She was the fastest girl in town. Beautiful legs. I finally caught up; we've been together ever since. They sit a moment. Below: Jack nails another one. 
[154]I wanted to apologize to you. 
[155]Everything. I can't apologize to him. He and I both knew what we were getting into. But you. A newlywed, trying to blossom a marriage under all this pressure. 
[156]Your husband has humbled me. When this all began I thought I was changing the world and that Jackie was my instrument. Can you imagine? I wish I could help him, but I'm just a spectator. 
[157]Is he able to get things off his chest? So he doesn't burn up? 
[158]Good. It's too much to carry inside. Does he have any friends on the team?  They're spectators, too. They do admire him though. Rachel looks out to where Reese and Stanky play catch. 
[159]Even the worst of us recognizes courage. Moral courage especially. I have to think they see it. Jackie's a man on trial. He's responding with glory and grace. No one can take their eyes off him. 
[160]I suppose we all are. You're an astute woman, Mrs. Robinson. 
[161]If I'd met you first, I wouldn't have looked so long for Jackie. 
[162]I mean if he was good enough for you, he's certainly good enough for the rest of us. 
[163]What can I do for you, Herb? 
[164]Twenty years. Maybe more. 
[165]And why's that, Herb? His name's Jackie Robinson by the way. 
[166]Herbert, what your team does is your decision. But my team is coming to Philadelphia. With Robinson. If we have to claim the game as a forfeit, we will. That's 9-0 in case you forgot. 
[167]Do you think God likes baseball? I do. 
[168]It means you're going to meet God one day, Herb, and when he inquires why Robinson wasn't on the field in Philadelphia and you answer because he was a Negro, it may not be a sufficient reply. As Rickey hangs up the phone... 
[169]What can I do for you, Pee Wee? 
[170]It's an important road trip, we're only three games out of first. 
[171]Cincinnati's nearly a home game for you. 
[172]Nigger lover. Watch yourself. We will get you, carpetbagger.  Typical stuff. Reese takes the letter back, a little hurt. 
[173]How many of these letters have you gotten, Pee Wee? 
[174]I'll tell you what they aren't, they aren't letters from the Jackie Robinson fan club. Here -- He thrusts a sheaf of it into Reese's hands. As Reese flips through the stack of hate, reads: 
[175]Of course he knows. And the FBI. They're taking a threat in Cincinnati pretty seriously. So excuse me if I'm not too shocked at you being called a carpetbagger. You should be proud of it! 
[176]I understand. I bet Jackie just wants to play ball. I bet he wishes he wasn't leading the league in hit by pitch. I bet he wishes people didn't want to kill him. But the world isn't so simple anymore. I'm not sure it ever was. We just, baseball ignored it. Now we can't. 
[177]Coming up out of his seat along with the fans around him. 
[178]Get out. Let me talk to my first baseman. Go. He's getting stitched up for Pete's sake. The reporters move off for other interviews. Reporter Two hesitant to let it go, finally drifts off. Rickey watches. 
[179]Sticking up for yourself is what you'd expect of any man. Some find it galling to see it in a Negro. 
[180]Sorry? Sorry for what? 
[181]I told you, Jackie, all the best base runners get caught sometimes. 
[182]Do you know what I saw this morning? I was passing a sandlot and a little white boy was up to bat. You know what he was doing? 
[183]He was pretending he was you. Wiping his hands on his pants, swinging with his arms outstretched like you do. A little white boy pretending he was a black man. 
[184]We had victory over fascism in Germany; it's time for victory over racism at home. 
[185]I love this game. I love baseball. I've given my life to it. Forty odd years ago I was a player coach at Ohio Wesleyan University. We had a Negro catcher, best hitter on the team. Charley Thomas. Rickey starts slowly rubbing the baseball in his hands. 
[186]A fine young man. I saw him laid low. Broken because of the color of his skin and I didn't do enough to help. I told myself I did, but I didn't. The game I loved had something unfair at the heart of it. I ignored it. But a time came when I could no longer do that. You let me love baseball again. Thank you. Jack's eyes gentle on Rickey's. 
[187]You're a force of nature, Jackie, you've complicated everything but yourself. You're changing the world, and refusing to let it change you. I for one am in awe. Jack reaches, takes the baseball from him. A beat as they consider each other. Finally, a promise... 
[188]Rickey here. 
[189]And eliminates the Giants and Boston. He puts an âX' through Boston and the Giants. The rest of the NL are already crossed out. Only the Cardinals remain. At the same time, Parrott X's the same out on his notebook. 
[190]We'd have to lose nearly every game for the Cardinals to catch us now. One more win may do it. Who's pitching tomorrow for the Pirates?
dialogues.JACK:
[1]What was I? The umpire passes one hand over the other: Safe. Jack looks over at the catcher, gives him a pointed look as he goes -- The catcher shoves him in the back. Jack turns, shoves back. As the two men wrestles each other to the ground -- 
[2]I'm going to the toilet. 
[3]Take that hose out of the tank. 
[4]Take it out. We'll get our ninety- nine gallons of gas someplace else. The attendant blinks. He takes a look from Jack to up and down the deserted highway. No business in sight. 
[5]Excuse me? 
[6]I think so. 
[7]I don't make much money. Between the army and now baseball I've been away a lot. And Rae, Rachel, she wants to finish school. Considering all that, I say I think so. 
[8]Yes, sir, very much. 
[9]Coach Sukeforth here said you were starting a new Negro League. That doesn't make sense to me. 
[10]What's this about, Mr. Rickey? 
[11]Yes, sir. That's fine. 
[12]My temper? 
[13]Yes. 
[14]Do you want a ballplayer who doesn't have the guts to fight back? Is that what you want? 
[15]Mr. Rickey, you give me a uniform, you give me a number on my back, and I'll give you the guts. 
[16]Rae, I'm in Brooklyn. 
[17]I don't want to say on the phone. In fact, I'm not supposed to tell anyone. She can hear the tingle in his voice. 
[18]I'm here, Rae 
[19]We've been tested you and me. Our loyalty, our faith. We've done everything the right way. Me trying to make money. You finishing school. Separated by the war, now by baseball. We don't owe the world a thing. Only each other. She's actually getting a little scared now. 
[20]The Brooklyn Dodgers just signed me to play ball up in Montreal. It might lead to bigger things. To something wonderful. 
[21]Rae. Will you marry me? 
[22]Now. 
[23]Yes. They reach the door. Jack gets out a key to unlock it. Rachel looks nervous, steps back across the hall. 
[24]Everyone looked happy. I've never seen so many people looking happy. 
[25]Too late. You already do. It's you and me, Rae. 
[26]It can wait one more night Are you coming, Mrs. Robinson? 
[27]I will, Mama. Mallie hugs Jack and then kisses Rachel. 
[28]They have food on the plane, Mama. 
[29]I couldn't tell her no. 
[30]No one's going to mistake you for a bumpkin in this. 
[31]The flight to Pensacola leaves in an hour... You okay? 
[32]We're not in Pasadena anymore. A sudden momentum carries her forward. 
[33]Honey... Rae -- 
[34]I promised Mr. Rickey we'd stay out of trouble. 
[35]Before I promised. 
[36]Excuse me? 
[37]No. You hang onto those. Mastering himself, Jack slides out. Drilling the cook with a look, he offers his hand to Rachel as she slides out as well. 
[38]Just a hop to Daytona now. As Rachel nods, an AIRLINE EMPLOYEE boards, MISS BISHOP. She makes her way over. She spots who she's looking for. 
[39]When's the next flight? 
[40]Look, I'm with the Brooklyn Dodger organization. I've got to get down to Daytona. I'm supposed to report to spring training in the morning. 
[41]You gave away our seats! Get us back on that plane! Miss Bishop picks up a PHONE, holds it in Jack's face. 
[42]Mama knew... He holds it out to Rachel. She slides over, takes it, takes a bite as well, smiles at him. He smiles back. 
[43]My who? 
[44]You got a car? Get us out of here. 
[45]It's a joke, right? 
[46]I'll try to remember... 
[47]It's okay. 
[48]That's all I got. 
[49]If they ask something, I'll answer. 
[50]Sure, I had no problem with white men in the service or at UCLA. 
[51]I'll duck. That gets some laughs. 
[52]Reese plays for Brooklyn. I'm worried about making Montreal. 
[53]It's about getting paid. Jack doing beautifully. Smith breathes a sigh of relief... 
[54]I'm just a ballplayer, Mr. Brock. 
[55]No thank you, sir, I don't drink. 
[56]Mr. Brock, do you have a desk? I'd like to get a letter to my wife. 
[57]I was just getting loose. Smith sticks his head in the door. 
[58]I wonder what he wants? 
[59]What are you talking about? The man close now. As Jack cranks down the window, Smith floors it. The Buick SCREECHES away, SWERVING around a CAR coming the other way. 
[60]What the hell, Wendell?! 
[61]Why didn't you say so? 
[62]I thought you woke me because I was cut from the team. Jack LAUGHS harder. Wendell LAUGHS as well. As it fades, Jack looks back over his shoulder. Jesus... 
[63]What!? Why? 
[64]You swing that thing you better hit me between the eyes with it. 
[65]I said okay, Skipper, tell him... Ah'm a-gittin'. Sho'nuff, ah is. 
[66]I did. Then I took a long shower. We lost 2 to 1. She takes a few exaggerated steps to amuse him. 
[67]You're not getting away from me.
